consists of (i) a program cluster for the FMPARP of $105 million;

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  the  Fiscal 
Management and Public Administration Reform Program (FMPARP) in the Islamic Republic of 
Afghanistan  comprising  (i)  a  proposed  program  cluster  on  fiscal  management  and  public 
administration  reforms  in  Afghanistan,  (ii)  a  proposed  program  loan  for  subprogram  1  of  the 
FMPARP  (the  Program)  and  (iii)  a  proposed  grant  for  Capacity  Building  for  Institutional 
Development (the Project or the Grant).    
 

II. 

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 

 
2. 
Afghanistan has made significant progress in achieving macroeconomic stability over the 
last 3 years. Gross domestic product (GDP) is estimated to have grown by 28.6% in fiscal year 
(FY)  2003  and  by  15.7%  in  FY2004.  In  FY2005,  growth  is  estimated  to  have  slowed  to  8.0%, 
largely  because  of  a  decline  in  agricultural  output  as  a  result  of  a  drought.  The  economy  is 
highly reliant on agriculture (37.2% of GDP, excluding opium production, in FY2005) and on the 
service  sector  (38.3%).  Sectors  linked  to  the  reconstruction  effort,  such  as  construction  and 
telecommunications,  continued  to  perform  well  in  FY2005.  Since  the  successful  currency 
conversion  in  early  2003,  prices  have  remained  broadly  stable  and  the  exchange  rate  has 
fluctuated  around  AF45–50  per  dollar,  reflecting  widespread  acceptance  of  the  new  currency 
and prudent macroeconomic and monetary policies. However, the opium economy has grown to 
record  levels  and  this  poses  one  of  the  country's  most  difficult  development  challenges. 
According to the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC), opium cultivation in 2004 
increased by 64%, which amounted to about 60% of the country's official GDP (see Appendix 1 
for key economic indicators). In 2005, opium production has fallen because of lower farm-gate 
prices and initial successes in the antinarcotics campaign. 
 
3. 
The  operating  budget  for  FY2005  was  set  at  $609  million,  with  $300  million  to  be 
generated  from  domestic  revenue  and  $309  million  to  be  covered  by  foreign  assistance. 
Domestic  revenues  met  the  more  conservative  target  under  the  International  Monetary  Fund 
(IMF) Staff Monitored Program (SMP), although they were below the budget forecast. Custom 
duties,  which  represent  about  55%  of  total  revenues,  rose  by  20%.  As  in  the  previous  year, 
operating expenditures also fell short of the budget targets. For instance, because of continued 
delays  in  recruiting  teachers  and  in implementing  the  main  civil  service  restructuring  program, 
expenditures  were  AF2.4  billion  short  of  the  midyear  review  projection  of  AF29.1  billion.  The 
development  budget,  approved  with  a  delay,  increased  from  $1.8  billion  in  FY2004  to  $4.2 
billion  in  FY2005.  Development  budget  spending  has  been  very  slow  and  continues  to  be 
hampered  by  the  volatile  security  situation;  capacity  constraints,  particularly  in  line  ministries; 
and the long lead time required for project design. 
 
The  consumer  price  index  (CPI)  rose  by  16.3%  in  FY2005  (year-on-year  change) 
4. 
reflecting  the  above  average  price  of  wheat  because  of  the  drought  and  sharp  increases  in 
housing  prices.  Monetary  policy  continues  to  focus  on  keeping  inflation  under  control  and  on 
ensuring  a  relatively  stable  exchange  rate.  A  regime  of  foreign  exchange  auctions  is  in  place. 
The  Central  Bank  successfully  introduced  a  short-term  capital  note  in  September  2004  and 
reserve  requirements  for  commercial  banks  have  been  adopted.  Afghanistan's  financial

year.  
 
5. 
Reliable balance of payment data are not available. Exports of goods (excluding opium, 
and  including  re-exports)  reached  $1.66  billion  in  FY2005.  Total  imports  amounted  to  $3.87 
billion.  According  to  UNODC,  the  value  of  opiate  exports  to  neighboring  countries  increased 
from $2.3 billion in 2003 to $2.8 billion in 2004. The current account deficit (excluding grants) is 
expected to amount to $2.7 billion (45.0% of GDP) in FY2005. The deficit was covered mainly 
by grants (if grants are included, the deficit was 0.7% of GDP).1  
 
6. 
Despite the strong economic recovery and progress in structural reforms, the remaining 
challenges  are  huge.  If  Afghanistan  is  to  shift  from  recovery-related  growth  to  long-term 
sustainable  development,  it  will  require  new  drivers  of  growth,  continued  commitment  to  the 
ambitious reform agenda, and sustained support from the international community. With a per 
capita GDP of only $253 per annum in FY2005, reducing poverty, or even attaining the income 
levels of neighboring countries, will require strong economic growth over the medium and long 
term  and  substantial  international  assistance. Given  the  size  of  the  opium  economy,  a  holistic 
strategy that creates alternative livelihoods in the rural economy, combined with interdiction and 
eradication measures and legal reform, is needed, supported by broad-based economic growth 
and sustained donor commitment. Finally, because of its limited capacity to deliver public goods 
and  services,  the  Government  will  require  concerted  actions  with  donors  and  civil  society  to 
create a sustainable environment of good governance to ensure effective service delivery. This 
will contribute to improved livelihoods and poverty reduction.

A.

guidelines on contingent liabilities, including guarantees, will be drawn up.

124.  Risks to FMPAR are multiple and can be classified according to the Program’s ability to 
affect or mitigate these risks.  
 
125.  External  risks  include:  (i)  security,  (ii)  political,  and  (iii)  macroeconomic  risks.  Internal 
risks include: (i) capacity constraints, (ii) governance, and (iii) donor coordination.   
 
126.  Security concerns pose the largest risk. A worsening security situation would have many 
impacts  on  the  FMPARP,  including  limiting  extending  reforms  to  the  subnational  level  of 
government.  If  the  security  situation  deteriorates,  operations  will  be  restricted  and  fielding 
consults  and  monitoring  will  be  more  difficult.  Political  risks  appear  to  be  contained,  following 
successful parliamentary and provincial elections. However, in a more politicized environment, 
decisive policy decisions may not be based on technical merit alone. Macroeconomic risks have 
decreased, following significant progress in building supporting infrastructure to ensure effective 
macroeconomic  management  and  overall  improvement  to  the  macroeconomic  stability 
framework.  
 
127.  Capacity  constraints  are  the  most  significant  internal  risks,  because  of  the  limited 
availability of skilled resources to implement the reform program. Governance risks include the 
power  of  vested  interests.  Revenue  administration  officials  may  be  co-opted  by  interests  that 
refuse to embrace change or by enterprises that want to override the legal system. There may 
also be scope for corruption. Donor coordination risks are acute in Afghanistan, where there is a 
significant donor presence in most ministries. Unless there is strong Government ownership of 
the reforms, combined with well coordinated programs, there is a risk of duplication ineffective 
assistance.

The  first  post-conflict  national  budget  for  Afghanistan  (fiscal  year  [FY]  2005)  was 
adopted by presidential decree in June 2004—about 3 months after the start of the fiscal year 
(FY) on 21 March. This was followed by a midyear review of the national development budget 
approved in December 2004. The Government approved its operating budget for FY2006 on 15 
March  2005,  before  the  start  of  the  fiscal  year.  This  was  an  important  achievement,  as  it 
enabled  the  Government  to  address  payment  delays  and  operating  expenditure  arrears  that 
occurred  the  previous  year.  An  interim  development  budget  was  approved  on  2  April  2005  to 
ensure  continuity  of  funding  to  ongoing  development  projects.  The  final  development  budget 
was approved in June 2005 to incorporate additional donor-funded projects. A midyear review of 
the FY2006 budget was finalized in November 2005. 
 
The  external  development  budget  is  a  commitment  of  resources  based  on  a  list  of 
3. 
individual  projects  that  are  classified  under  three  pillars:  pillar  1—human  capital;  pillar  2—
infrastructure;  and  pillar  3—enabling  environment,  for  development.  These  three  pillars  are 
broken into 16 consultative working groups composed of government officials and donors, and 6 
crosscutting  advisory  groups.  Because  of  differences  in  donors’  budget  cycles,  commitments 
are not available before the start of Afghanistan’s fiscal year. As a result, the resource envelope 
remains  an  indicative  figure.  This  explains  why  an  interim  development  budget  is  approved 
before the final development budget.   
 
4. 
In the revised FY2006 budget, the total planned expenditure is estimated at $5.7 billion 
(approximately  82%  of  GDP),  of  which  $4.8  billion  (84%  of  total)  will  be  for  the  development 
budget and $693 million (14% of total) will be for the operating budget (Table A2.1). Of the total 
planned development expenditure, approximately $1 billion or 21% will be disbursed through the 
core  budget  and  $2.2  billion  or  46%  directly  by  donors  to  implementing  agencies,  leaving  a 
funding gap of $1.6 billion or of 33% of the total. According to the revised FY2006 budget, 58% 
of the total budget is allocated for pillar 3 (up from 48% last year), compared with 27% for pillar 
2, and 14% for pillar 1. Allocations for both pillars 1 and 2 have declined since last year.    
 
5. 
About two-thirds of the operating budget is funded by domestic revenues and the other 
third  from  ARTF  and  LOTFA  (Table  A2.2).  The  operating  budget  is  nominally  in  balance1  and 
fiscal  expansion  remains  subject  to  prudent  growth  rates.  This  reflects  a  limited  absorptive 
capacity, unstable security conditions, and an overstretched cadre of qualified civil servants. At 
the same time, this shows potential for domestic revenue generation. A contingency provision of 
nearly $17 million is meant to operate as a reserve for unplanned expenditures within the year, 
and to maintain fiscal discipline. There is also a multiyear reserve of $183 million for the funding

6. 
Under  the  core  budget  (Table  A3.3),  wages  and  salaries  comprise  62%  of  operating 
expenditures.  In  the  past,  wages  and  salaries  had  been  growing  at  above  30%  per  year  and 
contributing to mounting fiscal stress. The rapid expansion of priority reform and restructuring, 
and  the  spillover  effects  on  wages  and  salaries  of  other  civil  servants,  in  part  to  offset  steep 
increases  in  housing  rentals,  may  explain  these  rapid  increases.  Purchase  of  goods  and 
services  are  the  next  most  important  item,  accounting  for  close  to  20%  of  operating 
expenditures. Finally, transfers and subsidies, and pension payments remain small at under 3% 
of operating expenditure, reflecting the limited safety nets in Afghanistan. 
 
7. 
According  to  the  FY2006  midyear  budget  review,  operating  expenditure  for  FY2006  is 
projected  to  increase  to  10%  of  GDP  from  9.4%  of  GDP  in  FY2005.  This  is  a  contained 
increase,  in  line  with  the  operating  principles  on  fiscal  prudence  set  forth  in  the  budget,  and 
comes against the backdrop of a 22% increase in nominal GDP and a 19% increase in domestic 
revenue. Planned development expenditure under the midyear FY 2006 budget is $4.8 billion, 
compared with $4.4 billion at the time of budget approval.  
 
8. 
The  budget  for  FY2006  was  developed  under  a  new  chart  of  accounts  that  will  allow 
functional  classification  according  to  expenditure  items  in  the  following  year.  In  the  meantime, 
operating  expenditures  are  accounted  for  by  the  ministries,  while  development  expenditure  is 
reported by program. The breakdown of expenditures in the FY2006 operating budget reveals 
that the Afghan National Army and National Police and Enforcement account for approximately 
43% of the total operating expenditure of ministries and agencies. This is followed by education 
and vocational training at approximately 20%, and health and nutrition at below 5%. 
 
C. 
 
The  total  operating  revenues  for  FY  2006  is  projected  at  $816  million.  This  comprises 
9. 
domestic revenue (tax and non-tax) collection, projected at $468 million (equivalent to 6.8% of 
GDP),  ARTF  funds  for  $280  million,  and  LOTFA  funds  for  $68  million.  Funding  to  and 
allocations  from  the  Counter-Narcotics  Trust  Fund  are  still  to  be  determined.  Total  revenue  in 
FY2006 is projected to increase by 46% compared to the previous year.  
 
10.  MOF  is  currently  implementing  a  five-year  tax  administration  plan  with  donor  funding 
available for the first 3 years. Under the plan, the large-taxpayer office will become operational. 
The  office  will  remove  impediments  to  revenue  collection  by  removing  nuisance  taxes  and 
eliminating tax holidays and other exemptions. In addition, tax identification numbers (TIN) will 
be  issued  more  vigorously  to  facilitate  compliance  with  and  enforcement  of  tax  laws.  As  of 
September  2005,  nearly  19,000  TINs  have  been  issued  in  Kabul  and  close  to  6,000  in  the 
provinces. Money changers, customs brokers licensing processes, and motor vehicle purchase 
will now require TIN registration.  
 
11. 
An  amendment  to  the  Revenue  Law  was  approved  in  May  2005.  Under  the  law,  the 
corporate  tax  rate  is  set  at  20%  for all  businesses.  Income  tax  is  set  at  a  two-tier  structure  of 
10% for annual income of up to AF1.2 million and 20% for income over AF1.2 million. The tax-
free  income  tax  threshold  is  set  at  AF150,000  per  annum.  Withholding  tax  on  wages  will  be

The Medium-Term Budgeting Framework and Results-Based Budget System 

 
A. 
 
The  medium-term  budgeting  framework  (MTBF)  is  a  useful  public  expenditure 
1.

support  better-targeted  resource  allocations  and  more  efficient  expenditure  outcomes.  The 
attached figure briefly describes the MTBF.  
 
2. 
The Need for Accurate Revenue Forecasts and an Aggregate Resource Envelope. 
The resource and expenditure allocations of commitments should be sustainable in the medium 
term. This implies that resource allocation should not exceed the aggregate of public revenues 
and  “sustainable”1  borrowing.  Accordingly,  estimates  and  forecasts  for  public  revenues  should 
be accurate, consistent, and unbiased. 
 
3. 
Allocating Budgets to Line Ministries. In a traditional budgetary management system, 
budget allocations to line ministries tend to be closely tied to previous annual allocations, with 
ministries  tending  to  spend  all  of  their  budgets  to  avoid  potential  cuts  in  the  following  years. 
However,  under  the  MTBF,  budgetary  allocations  to  line  ministries  are  driven  by  the  broader 
policy  objectives  of  the  Government,  as  guided  by  the  national  development  strategy  or  its 
equivalent.  Under  this  MTBF,  the  line  ministries  must  prioritize  expenditure  options  to  meet 
policy  objectives.  The  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)—at  times  in  coordination  with  Ministry  of 
Economy  and  Planning—must  assess  the  various  prioritized  budgetary  requests  from  line 
ministries within the context and constraints of the aggregate resource envelope. The decision 
of  the  MOF  is  based  on  objective  criteria—proposed  expenditures  delivering  broad  policy 
objectives  of  the  Government—rather  than  on  the  subjective  outcomes  of  face-to-face 
negotiations.

THE GOVERNMENT’S VISION OF THE PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION IN AFGHANISTAN 

 
1. 
After  years  of  war  and  centralized  state  control,  management  and  administrative 
systems and skills in Afghanistan are lacking, and Government infrastructure has been severely 
damaged.  The  Government’s  success  in  implementing  policies  depends  substantially  on  the 
competence, efficiency, and effectiveness of the civil service. A concerted and focused program 
for  the  renewal  and  transformation  of  public  administration  started  in  2000  to  remedy  these 
shortcomings.   
 
2. 
The  Independent  Administrative  Reform  and  Civil  Service  Commission  (IARCSC)  has 
been  designated  as  the  focal  point  for  a  comprehensive  and  strategic  approach  for  rebuilding 
the  public  service  involving  the  whole  Government.  The  approach  is  based  on  the  following 
principles: (i) the civil service must be (and must be perceived to be) loyal to the Government 
and  the  people  of  Afghanistan;  (ii)  short-term  priorities  must  be  tackled  first  and  urgently,  and 
longer-term  and  deeper  reforms  must  be  initiated;  and  (iii)  implementation  will  be  undertaken 
collaboratively, with close cooperation between IARCSC and other key agencies.  
 
3.

and lawful public administration that can contribute to the future peace, stability, and economic

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Afghanistan:  
 
The Fiscal Management and Public Administration Reform Program (FMPARP) will contribute to poverty 
reduction  by  strengthening  fiscal  management  and  public  administration  and  supporting  reforms  to 
improve fiduciary standards. Improvements in the budget process, financial management processes, and 
fiduciary  control  mechanisms  are  likely  to  encourage  more  donors  to  channel  funding  through  the 
Government  budget.  This  will,  in  turn,  lead  to  further  institutional  strengthening  and  state  building, 
essential to the consolidation of peace and economic recovery. FMPARP will also assist in enabling the 
country to better meet the challenges of the transition from responding to emergency needs and recovery- 
related growth to long-term sustainable development. 
 
The  Program  encourages  the  Government  to  adopt  a  more  participatory  approach  to  the  budgeting 
process, enhancing ownership and resource allocation. A more efficient allocation of public resources will 
be essential for poverty reduction. The reforms also aim to strengthen the public investment program with 
clearer prioritization and alignment with the National Development Strategy. This will help the Government 
to  more  effectively  direct  public  resources  to  meet  priority  needs,  to  monitor  the  flow  of  resources  and 
evaluate the impact of public spending. Assistance to the fiscal policy unit under FMPARP will also look at 
equity issues in relation to revenue transfers to provinces. 
 
Capacity building under the project grant of FMPARP will assist the Government in deepening its reform 
program  and  in  extending  its  services  beyond  Kabul,  which  is  crucial  for  progress  towards  poverty 
reduction, consolidation of the peace-building process, and government control. 
 
B. 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
There  are  limited  available  data  on  poverty  incidence  and  distribution.  Under  an  ADB  TA  (Poverty 
Assessment  and  Socioeconomic  and  Macroeconomic  Statistical  Capacity  Building)1  an  integrated  living 
standards survey is currently being conducted with preliminary results expected in mid-2006.  
 
Social  indicators,  while  improving,  are  still  very  low.  Delivery  of  essential  services  remains  largely 
dependent  on  continued  donor  support  and  poses  extreme  difficulties.  Basic  services  are  still  largely 
lacking,  particularly  in  remote  areas  and  areas  affected  by  continued  unrest.  Qualitative  information 
suggests that unemployment is a significant problem, especially among the young, which is compounded 
by  the  extremely  low  human  resource  capacity,  the  continued  influx  of  returning  refugees,  and  high 
population  growth  rates.  A  national  risk  and  vulnerability  survey  conducted  in  2003  estimated  that  per 
capita expenditures in rural areas amounted to $165 per year. The data suggest that 3.5 million of the 17.5 
million Afghans living in rural areas are extremely poor and 10.5 million vulnerable to extreme poverty.
